geostan 0.0.1
  • Reference

Generalized Linear Models

stan_glm.Rd

Fit a generalized linear model with (optional) exchangeable random effects.

stan_glm(
  formula,
  slx,
  re,
  data,
  ME = NULL,
  C,
  EV,
  family = gaussian(),
  prior = NULL,
  prior_intercept = NULL,
  prior_sigma = NULL,
  prior_nu = NULL,
  prior_tau = NULL,
  centerx = FALSE,
  scalex = FALSE,
  prior_only = FALSE,
  chains = 4,
  iter = 2000,
  refresh = 500,
  pars = NULL,
  control = list(adapt_delta = 0.95, max_treedepth = 15),
  silent = FALSE,
  ...
)

Arguments

formula

A model formula, following the R formula syntax. Binomial models are specified by setting the left hand side of the equation to a data frame of successes and failures, as in cbind(successes, failures) ~ x.
slx

Formula to specify any spatially-lagged covariates. As in, ~ x1 + x2 (the intercept term will be removed internally); you must also provide C when including slx. Specified covariates will be pre-multiplied by a row-standardized spatial weights matrix and then added (prepended) to the design matrix. If and when setting priors for beta manually, remember to include priors for any SLX terms as well.
re

If the model includes a varying intercept term (or "spatially unstructured random effect") specify the grouping variable here using formula synatax, as in ~ ID. The resulting random effects parameter returned is named alpha_re.
data

A data.frame or an object coercible to a data frame by as.data.frame containing the model data.
ME

To model observational error (i.e. measurement or sampling error) in any or all of the covariates or offset term, provide a named list. Errors are assigned a Gaussian probability distribution and the `true' covariate vector is assigned a Student's t model with optional spatially varying mean. Elements of the list ME (by name) may include:

se

a dataframe with standard errors for each observation; columns will be matched to the variables by column names. The names should match those from the output of model.matrix(formula, data).

bounded

If any variables in se are bounded within some range (e.g. percentages ranging from zero to one hundred) provide a vector of zeros and ones indicating which columns are bounded. By default the lower bound will be 0 and the upper bound 100, for percentages.

bounds

A numeric vector of length two providing the upper and lower bounds, respectively, of the bounded variables. Defaults to bounds = c(0, 100).

spatial

Logical value indicating if the models for covariates should include a spatially varying mean (using an eigenvector spatial filter). Defaults to spatial = FALSE. If spatial = TRUE and you do not provide both ME$prior_rhs and EV then you must provide a connectivity matrix C.

prior_rhs

Optional prior parameters for the regularized horseshoe (RHS) prior used for the ESF data model; only used if ME$spatial = TRUE. The RHS prior is used for the eigenvector spatial filter (ESF), as in stan_esf. Must be a named list containing vectors slab_df, slab_scale, scale_global, and varname. The character vector varname indicates the order of the other parameters (by name).

offset

if you have an offset term with measurement error, include a vector of standard errors to the list and assign it the name offset.
C

Optional spatial connectivity matrix which will be used to calculate residual spatial autocorrelation as well as any user specified slx or spatial ME terms; it will be row-standardized before calculating slx terms.
EV

A matrix of eigenvectors from any (transformed) connectivity matrix (presumably spatial). See make_EV and shape2mat.
family

The likelihood function for the outcome variable. Current options are poisson(link = "log"), binomial(link = "logit"), student_t(), and the default gaussian().
prior

A data.frame or matrix with location and scale parameters for Gaussian prior distributions on the model coefficients. Provide two columns---location and scale---and a row for each variable in their order of appearance in the model formula. Default priors are weakly informative relative to the scale of the data.
prior_intercept

A vector with location and scale parameters for a Gaussian prior distribution on the intercept; e.g. prior_intercept = c(0, 10).
prior_sigma

A vector with degrees of freedom, location and scale parameters for the half-Student's t prior on the residual standard deviation sigma. To use a half-Cauchy prior set degrees of freedom to one; e.g. prior_sigma = c(1, 0, 3).
prior_nu

Set the parameters for the Gamma prior distribution on the degrees of freedom in the likelihood function when using family = student_t. Defaults to prior_nu = c(alpha = 3, beta = 0.2).
prior_tau

Set hyperparameters for the scale parameter of exchangeable random effects/varying intercepts. The random effects are given a normal prior with scale parameter alpha_tau. The latter is given a half-Student's t prior with default of 20 degrees of freedom, centered on zero and scaled to the data to be weakly informative. To adjust it use, e.g., prior_tau = c(df = 20, location = 0, scale = 20).
centerx

Should the covariates be centered prior to fitting the model? Defaults to FALSE.
scalex

Should the covariates be centered and scaled (divided by their standard deviation)? Defaults to FALSE.
prior_only

Draw samples from the prior distributions of parameters only.
chains

Number of MCMC chains to estimate. Default chains = 4.
iter

Number of samples per chain. Default iter = 2000.
refresh

Stan will print the progress of the sampler every refresh number of samples. Defaults to 500; set refresh=0 to silence this.
pars

Optional; specify any additional parameters you'd like stored from the Stan model.
control

A named list of parameters to control the sampler's behavior. See stan for details. The defaults are the same rstan::stan excep that adapt_delta is raised to 0.95 and max_treedepth = 15.
silent

If TRUE, suppress printed messages including prior specifications and Stan sampling progress (i.e. refresh=0). Stan's error and warning messages will still print.
...

Other arguments passed to sampling. For multi-core processing, you can use cores = parallel::detectCores(), or run options(mc.cores = parallel::detectCores()) first.

Value

An object of class class geostan_fit (a list) containing:

summary

Summaries of the main parameters of interest; a data frame

diagnostic

Widely Applicable Information Criteria (WAIC) with crude measure of effective number of parameters (eff_pars) and mean log pointwise predictive density (lpd), and residual spatial autocorrelation (Moran coefficient of the residuals). Residuals are relative to the mean posterior fitted values.

stanfit

an object of class stanfit returned by rstan::stan

data

a data frame containing the model data

edges

The edge list representing all unique sets of neighbors

family

the user-provided or default family argument used to fit the model

formula

The model formula provided by the user (not including ESF component)

slx

The slx formula

re

A list containing re, the random effects (varying intercepts) formula if provided, and Data a data frame with columns id, the grouping variable, and idx, the index values assigned to each group.

priors

Prior specifications.

scale_params

A list with the center and scale parameters returned from the call to base::scale on the model matrix. If centerx = FALSE and scalex = FALSE then it is an empty list.

ME

The ME data list, if one was provided by the user for measurement error models.

spatial

NA, slot is maintained for use in geostan_fit methods.

Details

When family = student_t(), the parameter nu in the model refers to the degrees of freedom in the Student's t likelihood function for the data. Spatially lagged covariates will have w. prefixed to the variable name. Covarites with observational or measurement error (ME) models will be return with an x_ prefixed to the variable name.

Examples

library(ggplot2)
library(sf)
data(sentencing)

# using a small number of iterations and a single chain only for compilation speed
# optionally add W to calculate residual SA internally
W <- shape2mat(sentencing, "W")
sentencing$log_e <- log(sentencing$expected_sents)
fit.pois <- stan_glm(sents ~ offset(log_e),
                     re = ~ name,
                     family = poisson(),
                     data = sentencing,
                     C = W,
                    chains = 1,# chains = 4, cores = 4,
                    iter = 500) #iter = 2e3
#> 
#> *Setting prior parameters for intercept
#> Gaussian
#> Location: 0
#> Scale: 1.15103493100263
#> 
#> *Setting prior parameters for alpha_tau
#> Student's t
#> Degrees of freedom: 20
#> Location: 0
#> Scale: 1.15103493100263
#> 
#> SAMPLING FOR MODEL 'glm' NOW (CHAIN 1).
#> Chain 1: 
#> Chain 1: Gradient evaluation took 1.8e-05 seconds
#> Chain 1: 1000 transitions using 10 leapfrog steps per transition would take 0.18 seconds.
#> Chain 1: Adjust your expectations accordingly!
#> Chain 1: 
#> Chain 1: 
#> Chain 1: Iteration:   1 / 500 [  0%]  (Warmup)
#> Chain 1: Iteration: 251 / 500 [ 50%]  (Sampling)
#> Chain 1: Iteration: 500 / 500 [100%]  (Sampling)
#> Chain 1: 
#> Chain 1:  Elapsed Time: 0.102533 seconds (Warm-up)
#> Chain 1:                0.05476 seconds (Sampling)
#> Chain 1:                0.157293 seconds (Total)
#> Chain 1: 
#> Warning: Bulk Effective Samples Size (ESS) is too low, indicating posterior means and medians may be unreliable.
#> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See
#> http://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#bulk-ess
#> Warning: Tail Effective Samples Size (ESS) is too low, indicating posterior variances and tail quantiles may be unreliable.
#> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See
#> http://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#tail-ess

# diagnostics plot: Rhat values should all by very near 1
library(rstan)
rstan::stan_rhat(fit.pois$stanfit)
#> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
 # see effective sample size for all parameters and generated quantities
 # (including residuals, predicted values, etc.)
rstan::stan_ess(fit.pois$stanfit)
#> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
# or for a particular parameter
rstan::stan_ess(fit.pois$stanfit, "alpha_re")
#> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
library(bayesplot)
yrep <- posterior_predict(fit.pois)
y <- sentencing$sents
ppc_dens_overlay(y, yrep[1:100,])
# map standardized incidence (sentencing) ratios
E <- sentencing$expected_sents
sentencing@data$ssr <- fitted(fit.pois)$mean / E
ggplot(data=st_as_sf(sentencing),
      aes(fill = ssr)) +
 geom_sf() +
 scale_fill_gradient2(midpoint = 1) +
 theme_bw() +
 ggtitle("Standardized state prison sentencing ratios, 1905-1910")
